TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Nausea, NSTEMI, s/p Cath lab with 2 bare metal stents
   to SVG-OM
   24 Hour Events:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8912**] is a 70 yo man with CAD s/p CABX [**2192**] (LIMA-LAD, SVT to
   RPDA and SVG to OM), diastolic CHF, PVD who was admitted to vascular
   surgery for L fem-[**Doctor Last Name 114**] bypass on [**5-4**] for thrombosed R popliteal
   aneurysm.  His operation was uncomplicated, but post-op at 3am he
   developed nausea & diaphoresis.  EKG showed lateral ST depressions &
   STE in III and aVR.  In this setting he developed hypoxia (SaO2 high
   80's on 100% NRB), & hypotension to the 80's for several hours.  First
   set of CE's were markedly positive with CK 1192 and trop 0.8.
   Cardiology was consulted who recommended urgent cardiac
   catheterization.
   .
   In the cath lab, he was found to have an acute occlusion of his SVG to
   OM1 graft.  Clot was suctioned from the graft and 2 bare metal stents
   were placed with good effect.  His BP improved with this intervention
   and he began making tood urine.  The rest of his coronaries showed
   native disease similar to prior cath.
   .
   On arrival to the CCU, vitals 97.1 126/64 73 26 87% on 4L.  Pt was
   given 40mg IV lasix and put on a non-rebreather with improvement of his
   sats to mid-upper-90's.  Pt was loaded with plavix and continued on
   integrelin drip.
   Allergies:
   Lipitor (Oral) (Atorvastatin Calcium)
   Arthralgia/Arth
   Ciprofloxacin
   Unknown;
   Trimethoprim
   Unknown;
   Bactrim (Oral) (Sulfamethoxazole/Trimethoprim)
   Rash;
   Atenolol
   Lightheadedness
   Crestor (Oral) (Rosuvastatin Calcium)
   Unknown;
   Zetia (Oral) (Ezetimibe)
   Unknown;
   Vicodin (Oral) (Hydrocodone Bit/Acetaminophen)
   Unknown;
   Cephalexin
   Unknown;
   Amlodipine
   Lightheadedness
   Quinapril
   Lightheadedness
   Spironolactone
   Unknown;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Eptifibatide (Integrilin) - 2 mcg/Kg/min
   Other ICU medications:
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   70M thrombosed R popliteal aneurysm s/p R CFA-PT(R cephalic) [**5-4**]
   PMH:
   # Hypertension
   # Hypercholesterolemia
   # CABG x 3 [**2192**]: LIMA to LAD, SVG to RPDA, SVG to OM
   # Diastolic heart failure
   # CKD with baseline Creatinine:1.4
   # PVD:
   # Left CEA [**1-8**]
   # Abdominal aortic aneurysm 5.0 x 4.0 with eccentric mural thrombus
   s/p endovascular repair on [**2198-1-8**] c/b postoperative pneumonia and
   herpes zoster.
   # RAS s/p renal stenting, hypogastric coiling [**2198-1-2**]
   # Sleep apnea- has CPAP but does not use frequently
   # Prior smoking- 150 pack years
   # Orcheitis [**1-/2198**]
   # Left testicular surgery [**2196**]
   # Gout--in record, pt denies
   # Kidney stones
   # Gerd
   # Umbilical hernia repair [**4-11**]
   .
   MEDS:
   Isosorbide monontirate 30mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Omeprazole 20mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Allopurinol 300mg daily
   Aspirin 81mg 2 tablets daily
   Magnesium Oxide 400mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Metoprolol succinate 50mg
 tablet [**Hospital1 **]
   Hydralazine 10mg TID
   Furosemide 20mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Potassium 20meq daily
   Study medication ? from Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2731**] for Tra2P TIMI 50
   .
   Allergies: Lipitor, Cipro, Trimeth/Sulfa, Atenolol, Crestor, Zetia,
   Vicodin, hydrchlorthiazide, Cephalexin, Amlodipine, Spironolactone,
   Quinapril
   .
   Social History: Former heavy smoker, 150 pack years
   .
   Family History: Unknown
   .
   Cardiac enzymes: CK 1192, CK-MB 219, CK, trop 0.82
   [**2198-1-8**] p-MIBI
   Partially reversible mid-anterior wall mild defect. The calculated
   left ventricular ejection fraction is 48%.
   .
   Cardiac catheterization: [**2198-5-5**] -
   Coronary Angiography - right dominant
   LMCA:  subtotally occluded
   LAD:  proximally occluded; distal vessel fills via LIMA
   LCX:  diffuse proximal/mid disease; SVG to major OM seen to be occluded
   RCA:  not injected; known severely diffusely diseased
   SVG-OM: proximally occluded with acute appearance of thrombus
   LIMA-LAD:  normal
   SVG-RPDA:  mild disease
   .
   SVG-OM - dilated and stented with overlapping 4.5x28 and 5.0x18 Ultra
   stents with no residual, normal flow.
   .
   [**1-/2198**] ECHO
   The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is severe symmetric left
   ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal.
   Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Transmitral Doppler
   and tissue velocity imaging are consistent with Grade I (mild) LV
   diastolic dysfunction. The gradient increased with the Valsalva
   manuever. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are
   normal. The aortic root is moderately dilated at the sinus level. The
   aortic arch is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly
   thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1+) aortic
   regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are moderately
   thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. No mitral regurgitation
   is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests impaired
   relaxation. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. The
   pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is an
   anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad.
   .
   IMPRESSION: Severe left ventricular hypertrophy with hyperdynamic left
   ventricular systolic function. Mild diastolic dysfunction. Mild
   inducible outflow tract greadient. Moderately dilated aortic root. Mild
   aortic regurgitation.
   .
   [**2198-5-4**] CXR
   Portable AP chest radiograph was compared to [**2198-1-10**].
   The internal jugular line tip is at the level of low SVC. The patient
   is in mild volume overload. Otherwise, no significant changes have been
   demonstrated. No pneumothorax is seen.
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Constitutional: No(t) Fever
   Ear, Nose, Throat: No(t) Epistaxis
   Cardiovascular: No(t) Chest pain, No(t) Palpitations, No(t) Edema,
   No(t) Tachycardia
   Nutritional Support: NPO
   Respiratory: No(t) Cough, Wheeze
   Genitourinary: Foley
   Musculoskeletal: left arm pain
   Integumentary (skin): No(t) Jaundice, No(t) Rash
   Heme / Lymph: No(t) Anemia, No(t) Coagulopathy
   Neurologic: No(t) Numbness / tingling
   Psychiatric / Sleep: No(t) Agitated
   Allergy / Immunology: No(t) Immunocompromised

   Extremities: Right: Absent, Left: Absent

        [image002.jpg]
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8912**] is a 70 yo man with CAD s/p CABG in [**2192**], diastolic CHF,
   severe PVD who presents with post-operative NSTEMI & CHF.  Pt taken to
   cath lab with placement of 2 bare metal stents to SVG--OM graft.
   .
   # NSTEMI/CAD: presenting with likely ACS from acute occlusion of SVG.
   Two Ultra bare metal stents place in SVG-OM.  Pt transferred on ICU on
   integrelin.
   - aspirin
   - plavix load, then daily
   - uptitrate metoprolol to 25mg po tid
   - recheck lipid panel and address numerous statin allergies, pt
   currently written for simvastatin but had been refusing on the vascular
   service
   - will start low dose ACE
   - post-cath check at 1:30
   - 2pm post-cath labs
   - ECHO on arrival to ICU for evaluation of mitral regurg in setting of
   ichemic episode
   .
   # Diastolic CHF: with acute exacerbation likely related to volume
   overload + ischemia, EF > 55%
   - diurese with goal - 1-2L today
   - wean O2 as tolerated
   - ECHO on arrival to the ICU
   - atrovent for wheezing
   .
   # Hypertension - on metoprolol and hydralazine at baseline
   - titrate metoprolol for tight BP control
   - start low dose ACE inhibitor
   .
   # Rhythm - Sinus
   .
   # PVD s/p bypass - [**2198-5-4**] L SFA-PT (R cephalic)
   - vascular following, appreciate recs
   - continue BBlocker and statin
   .
   # Hypercholesterolemia - continue statin if patient will allow
   - further discuss ongoing statin therapy with patient
   - uptitrate statin
   .
   # CKD - baseline Cr 1.5, Pt received dye load with cath, however, have
   to hold post-cath fluids [**2-5**] pulmonary edema and CHF
   - continue to monitor creatinine and urine output
   .
   # Obstructive Sleep Apnea - has history and home CPAP machine with him
   - CPAP nightly on home settings
   .
   # FEN/GI - NPO for now while somnolent, once flatus+ can advance diet
   per vasc surgeries recs, currently no bowel sounds, bowel regimen,
   replete lytes prn
   .
   # PPX - sc heparin, no pneumoboot on left leg [**2-5**] new graft, IS,
   continue PPI
   .
   # Access - RIJ, A-line
   .
   # Code - Full Code
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2198-5-5**] 11:40 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2198-5-5**] 11:41 AM
   Multi Lumen - [**2198-5-5**] 11:42 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male who underwent vascular surgery for a thrombosed right popliteal aneurysm and developed post-operative nausea, diaphoresis, and cardiac enzymes consistent with an acute myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). The patient was taken to the catheterization lab where an acute occlusion of the SVG-OM graft was found, and two bare metal stents were placed with good effect.

The patient is currently admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with the following diagnoses:

1. NSTEMI/CAD: presenting with likely ACS from acute occlusion of SVG-OM graft.
2. Diastolic CHF: with acute exacerbation likely related to volume overload and ischemia.
3. Hypertension: on metoprolol and hydralazine at baseline.
4. PVD s/p bypass: with a history of left femoral-popliteal bypass and right cephalic femoral-popliteal bypass.
5. Hypercholesterolemia: with a history of statin therapy and multiple statin allergies.
6. CKD: with a baseline creatinine of 1.4 and receipt of dye load with catheterization.
7. Obstructive Sleep Apnea: with a history of sleep apnea and use of home CPAP machine.
8. FEN/GI: with a history of gastrointestinal issues and currently NPO due to somnolence.
9. PPX: with a history of pulmonary embolism and current use of sc heparin.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: such as recurrent myocardial infarction, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory complications: such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or respiratory failure.
3. Renal complications: such as acute kidney injury or worsening of chronic kidney disease.
4. Neurological complications: such as stroke, seizures, or altered mental status.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: such as gastrointestinal bleeding, bowel obstruction, or pancreatitis.
6. Infections: such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or surgical site infection.
7. Bleeding complications: such as hematoma, hemorrhage, or bleeding diathesis.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 8912**] is a 70 yo man with CAD s/p CABG in [**2192**], diastolic CHF,

   .

 poorly controlled lipid panel

   -consider cholestyramine
   .

   load with cath.
   - hold post-cath fluids [**2-5**] pulmonary edema and CHF
   - continue to monitor creatinine and urine output
   .

   - CPAP nightly on home settings
   .
   # FEN/GI
advance diet today, bowel regimen, replete lytes prn

Summary:

The patient, a 70-year-old man with a history of CAD, CABG, and diastolic CHF, was admitted to the ICU with post-op STEMI and CHF. He underwent catheterization and placement of two bare metal stents in the SVG-OM graft. The patient's condition has been complicated by new regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation, and mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 143/79 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 98%. The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, CK levels, and a mild increase in creatinine.

The patient's medical history includes CAD, CABG, diastolic CHF, severe PVD, and obstructive sleep apnea. He is taking various medications, including ASA, plavix, simvastatin, and captopril.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* Continued cardiac dysfunction and CHF
	* Risk of cardiac arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death
	* Potential for cardiac tamponade or pericarditis
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Pneumonia or VAP
	* Respiratory failure
	* Oxygen toxicity
3. Renal complications:
	* Acute kidney injury or worsening of chronic kidney disease
	* Fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances
	* Risk of renal failure
4. Neurological complications:
	* Cerebral edema or infarction
	* Seizures or stroke
	* Neurological deterioration
5. Infectious complications:
	* Sepsis or septic shock
	* Pneumonia or VAP
	* Bloodstream infections
6. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
	* Pancreatitis or cholecystitis
	* Malnutrition or dehydration
7. Hematological complications:
	* Bleeding or thrombocytopenia
	* Coagulopathy or disseminated intravascular coagulation
	* Anemia or bleeding
8. Metabolic complications:
	* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia
	* Electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disorders
	* Malnutrition or dehydration

These potential complications require close monitoring and prompt management to prevent morbidity and mortality.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU for post-operative STEMI and CHF following a femoral bypass procedure. The patient has a history of CAD, diastolic CHF, and severe PVD.

The patient's 24-hour events include the placement of an arterial line and multi-lumen line, as well as an EKG which showed ST depressions slightly worse than previously seen. The patient reported nausea shortly after arrival to the floor but has since improved. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 143/79 mmHg and a heart rate of 82 bpm.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating ongoing myocardial injury. The patient's ECHO showed moderate symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy, mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, and mild aortic regurgitation.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued integrillin post-cath
* Cont ASA, consider incr. plavix to 150 mg daily if concern for ongoing ischemia
* Uptitrate BB, ACEi for further afterload reduction given mitral valve involvement
* Cont simvastatin, monitor for ADR; consider cholestyramine as alternative
* Diuresis goal of 500mL negative
* Wean O2 as tolerated
* Atrovent nebs prn
* Cautious with antihypertensives as BP borderline
* Cont current regimen with holding parameters
* Cont captopril

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with ongoing regional dysfunction
* Chronic diastolic and acute systolic heart failure
* Hypertension
* Hypercholesterolemia
* Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
* Obstructive sleep apnea
* Gastrointestinal (GI) complications from the bypass procedure
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Stress ulcer and bleeding
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU for post-operative STEMI and CHF following femoral bypass surgery. The patient has a history of CAD, s/p CABG, diastolic CHF, and severe PVD.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Acute occlusion of the SVG-OM1 with placement of 2 bare metal stents, which may be causing ongoing ischemia.
2. New regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with infero-lateral akinesis, which is concerning for papillary muscle involvement.
3. Mitral valve involvement, which may require further afterload reduction.
4. Acute on chronic diastolic/acute systolic CHF with new regional dysfunction, requiring diuresis and oxygen therapy.
5. Hypercholesterolemia with poorly controlled lipid panel, which may require further management.
6. CKD with elevated creatinine levels, which may require further monitoring and management.
7. Obstructive Sleep Apnea with a history of home CPAP machine use.
8. FEN/GI issues with no bowel sounds and a need for bowel regimen and electrolyte repletion.
9. PPX with sc heparin and no pneumoboot on the left leg.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Ongoing ischemia and infarction due to the acute occlusion of the SVG-OM1.
2. Worsening of CHF symptoms due to the new regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction.
3. Development of atrial fibrillation or other arrhythmias due to the mitral valve involvement.
4. Progression of CKD due to the elevated creatinine levels.
5. Respiratory failure due to the obstructive sleep apnea and FEN/GI issues.
6. Infection or sepsis due to the PPX and presence of central lines.

The patient's care plan includes:

1. Integrillin post-cath to prevent further thrombosis.
2. Continuation of ASA and consideration of increasing Plavix to 150 mg daily if concern for ongoing ischemia.
3. Uptitration of beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors for further afterload reduction.
4. Continuation of simvastatin and monitoring for adverse drug reactions.
5. Diuresis goal of -1-2L and weaning of oxygen therapy as tolerated.
6. Use of atrovent nebs as needed.
7. Cautious use of antihypertensives due to borderline blood pressure.
8. Continued monitoring of creatinine and urine output.
9. Management of FEN/GI issues with bowel regimen and electrolyte repletion.
10. Continued use of CPAP machine for obstructive sleep apnea.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old man who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and was admitted to the ICU with post-operative non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and congestive heart failure (CHF). He was taken to the catheterization lab and had two bare metal stents placed in a saphenous vein graft (SVG) to SVG-OM graft. He was started on integrelin, aspirin, and clopidogrel, and his medications were adjusted to include metoprolol, captopril, and simvastatin.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T, creatine kinase (CK), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, indicating myocardial damage. His echocardiogram shows moderate left ventricular hypertrophy, mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, and mild mitral and aortic regurgitation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 82 beats per minute, blood pressure of 143/79 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula. His respiratory support includes oxygen therapy and atropine for wheezing.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's myocardial damage and left ventricular systolic dysfunction increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's wheezing and mild pulmonary artery hypertension increase the risk of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Renal complications: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) increase the risk of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease progression.
4. Infectious complications: The patient's indwelling catheters and medical devices increase the risk of infection, such as central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of hyperlipidemia and recent use of statins increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as pancreatitis and hepatitis.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of stroke and recent use of anticoagulants increase the risk of neurological complications, such as intracranial hemorrhage and stroke.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   [**Known lastname 8912**] is a 70 year old man who developed a posterior STEMI
   following vascular surgery repair of his left popliteal aneurysm.
   Cardiac catheterization demonstrated a thrombotic occlusion of the SVG
   to the OMB and two bare metal stent were placed.  He received aspirin,
   plavix and integrillin.  He developed recurrent nausea immediately
   after the procedure associated with persistent ST depressions, but this
   resolved.  He has multiple intolerances to statins and Zetia and has an
   LDL cholesterol = 197.  As a outpatient, we might consider the addition
   of cholestyramine as a bile acid sequestrant.  This afternoon, he
   developed [**3-13**] recurrent pain associated with some deepening of the ST
   segment depression.  This was controlled with IV NTG and he is now
   painfree.  We will cycle his enzymes and consider repeat
   catheterization for refractory pain or elevation of his cardiac
   enzymes.   Our plan is outlined above and involved implementation of IV
   heparin and NTG and continuation of his aspirin and clopidogrel.  This
   plan was communicated with the patient and all questions were
   addressed.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 70-year-old man, was admitted to the ICU for post-operative complications after undergoing femoral bypass surgery and cardiac catheterization. He developed a posterior STEMI, which was treated with placement of two bare metal stents in the SVG-OM graft. The patient's condition has been unstable, with recurrent pain and deepening ST segment depression.

Physically, the patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 143/79 mmHg. He has a moderate degree of regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, with mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction and infero-lateral akinesis. There is no evidence of atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, or pericardial effusion.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, with a peak value of 8.83 ng/mL. His creatinine level is elevated at 1.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 29 mg/dL. His complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 14.7 K/uL and a platelet count of 218 K/uL.

The patient's medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, integrillin, and heparin, and he is receiving IV NTG and omeprazole. His diet is being advanced, and he is receiving bowel regimen and electrolyte repletion as needed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Ongoing ischemia: The patient's recurrent pain and deepening ST segment depression suggest ongoing ischemia, which may require further intervention.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of CAD and cardiac catheterization may increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation or ventricular tachycardia.
3. Heart failure: The patient's moderate degree of regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction and mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction may increase his risk of heart failure.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's history of COPD and sleep apnea may increase his risk of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.
5. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and BUN level may indicate acute kidney injury, which may require further evaluation and management.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal surgery and medication use may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or obstruction.
7. Infection: The patient's history of surgery and prolonged hospitalization may increase his risk of infection, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or surgical site infection.

Based on the patient's condition and laboratory results, it is recommended that he receive close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male admitted for femoral bypass surgery, post-operative posterior ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), and acute on chronic diastolic/acute systolic congestive heart failure (CHF).

The patient's condition has been improving, with cardiac markers trending down and a decrease in chest pain. However, there are several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Recurrent graft occlusion: The patient's SVG-OM1 has been occluded, and there is a risk of recurrent graft occlusion, which can lead to further cardiovascular events.
2. Delirium: The patient is suspected to have ICU delirium, which can be a sign of underlying sepsis, electrolyte imbalance, or medication toxicity. Close monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent further complications.
3. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient has poorly controlled hypercholesterolemia, which can increase the risk of cardiovascular events. Statin therapy may need to be adjusted or alternative medications considered.
4. Chronic kidney disease (CKD): The patient has CKD, which can worsen with continued diuretic therapy. Close monitoring of creatinine and urine output is necessary.
5. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is borderline high, and cautious antihypertensive therapy is necessary to avoid hypotension.
6. Mitral valve involvement: The patient's symptoms may be related to possible mitral valve involvement, which can lead to further cardiovascular complications.
7. Respiratory support: The patient requires nasal cannula oxygen and may need further respiratory support, such as non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).
8. Gastrointestinal (GI) issues: The patient has a history of GI issues and may require further monitoring and treatment to prevent complications.

The patient's plan includes:

* Cardiac catheterization today with pretreatment with mucolytic and sodium bicarbonate
* Continued heparin and nitroglycerin therapy
* Uptitration of beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors for further afterload reduction
* Monitoring for adverse reactions to statin therapy and consideration of alternative medications
* Close monitoring of creatinine and urine output in patients with CKD
* Cautious antihypertensive therapy to avoid hypotension
* Further respiratory support as needed
* Monitoring for GI issues and treatment as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old man admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of post-operative STEMI and CHF following femoral bypass surgery. He has a history of CAD, PVD, and CKD. His current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, and captopril. He has been experiencing worsening chest pain, shortness of breath, and decreased urine output.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8°F, heart rate of 68 bpm, and blood pressure of 101/56 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 97% on a nasal cannula at 2L.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a new regional wall motion abnormality on echo, with an LVEF of 40-45%. He has a history of mitral valve involvement and is at risk for ongoing ischemia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin and CK-MB levels, indicating myocardial infarction. His creatinine level is 1.7 mg/dL, and his urine output is decreased.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ongoing ischemia: The patient's history of CAD and PVD, as well as his current symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath, put him at risk for ongoing ischemia.
2. CHF: The patient's diagnosis of CHF and his current symptoms of shortness of breath and decreased urine output put him at risk for further exacerbation of his condition.
3. Kidney injury: The patient's history of CKD and his current creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL put him at risk for further kidney injury.
4. Pulmonary edema: The patient's diagnosis of CHF and his current symptoms of shortness of breath put him at risk for pulmonary edema.
5. Infection: The patient's history of PVD and his current symptoms of fever and chills put him at risk for infection.
6. Bleeding: The patient's history of PVD and his current use of anticoagulant medications put him at risk for bleeding.
7. Thrombosis: The patient's history of PVD and his current use of anticoagulant medications put him at risk for thrombosis.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of chest pain. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, and is on multiple medications, including plavix, statins, and omeprazole. The patient's 24-hour events include the administration of lasix, statin, and omeprazole, as well as the placement of a PT C/S and the start of heparin and nitroglycerin infusions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8°F, heart rate of 68 bpm, and blood pressure of 101/56 mmHg.

Potential medical complications:

1. Delirium/Confusion: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and peripheral vascular disease, combined with the use of multiple medications, increases the risk of delirium and confusion.
2. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD): The patient's history of CAD and the administration of plavix, a platelet inhibitor, may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Peripheral Vascular Disease (PVD): The patient's history of PVD and the administration of heparin, a blood thinner, may increase the risk of bleeding complications, such as hematoma or hematuria.
4. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and the administration of omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor, may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Worsening Renal Function: The patient's history of kidney disease and the administration of lasix, a diuretic, may increase the risk of worsening renal function.
6. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's history of kidney disease and the administration of diuretics, such as lasix, may increase the risk of electrolyte imbalance, such as hypokalemia or hyperkalemia.
7. Infection: The patient's history of peripheral vascular disease and the administration of heparin, a blood thinner, may increase the risk of infection, such as cellulitis or sepsis.
8. Respiratory Complications: The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and the administration of oxygen therapy may increase the risk of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and previous coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), who was admitted for femoral bypass surgery with post-operative posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and acute on chronic heart failure (HF). The patient has a history of severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD) and is currently undergoing treatment for acute occlusion of the SVG-OM1 with placement of two bare metal stents.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Cardiac markers are trending down, but the patient still has ongoing chest pain associated with worsening graft occlusion.
* The patient has a history of CAD, HF, and PVD, which increases the risk of cardiac complications.
* The patient is on various medications, including heparin, aspirin, and clopidogrel, which may increase the risk of bleeding.
* The patient has a history of hypercholesterolemia, which is poorly controlled, and is currently taking statin therapy.
* The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD), which may increase the risk of worsening renal function.
* The patient has a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and is using a home continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac complications, such as further cardiac arrest, arrhythmias, or worsening HF.
* Bleeding complications due to the patient's anticoagulation therapy and invasive procedures.
* Worsening renal function due to the patient's underlying CKD and potential nephrotoxicity of certain medications.
* Respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), due to the patient's history of OSA and potential respiratory compromise.
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or bleeding, due to the patient's history of PUD and potential gastrointestinal toxicity of certain medications.
* Delirium or encephalopathy due to the patient's underlying medical conditions and potential medication side effects.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac markers and adjust therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust therapy as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust therapy as needed.
* Consider adjusting the patient's anticoagulation therapy to minimize the risk of bleeding complications.
* Consider adjusting the patient's diuretic therapy to minimize the risk of worsening renal function.
* Consider adjusting the patient's respiratory therapy to minimize the risk of respiratory complications.
* Consider adjusting the patient's gastrointestinal therapy to minimize the risk of gastrointestinal complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and subsequently developed a posterior STEMI following vascular surgery repair of his left popliteal aneurysm. He received cardiac catheterization and placement of two bare metal stents. The patient has been experiencing recurrent nausea and persistent ST depressions, but has been pain-free for the past 24 hours.

The patient's current medications include:

* Heparin sodium
* Aspirin
* Plavix
* Integrillin
* Simvastatin
* Clopidogrel
* Amlodipine
* Quinapril
* Spironolactone

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 14.7-9.6 x 10^9/L

* Plt: 54 x 10^9/L

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Recurrent graft occlusion: The patient's history of recurrent graft occlusion and persistent ST depressions may indicate a high risk of recurrent graft occlusion, which can lead to further cardiac complications.
2. Diastolic heart failure: The patient's history of diastolic heart failure and severe peripheral vascular disease may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
3. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's history of poorly controlled hypercholesterolemia may increase the risk of cardiovascular events, such as myocardial infarction and stroke.
4. Chronic kidney disease: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and high creatinine levels may increase the risk of kidney damage and failure.
5. Delirium: The patient's history of delirium and suspected ICU delirium may indicate a high risk of cognitive decline and increased risk of falls and other complications.
6. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension and borderline blood pressure may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure and stroke.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and oxygen therapy may increase the risk of respiratory failure and other respiratory complications.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and low sodium diet may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and other gastrointestinal complications.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current assessment and plan include:

* Cardiac catheterization today to assess for recurrent graft occlusion and to determine the cause of the patient's persistent ST depressions.
* Continue aspirin and clopidogrel therapy.
* Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust antihypertensive medications as necessary.
* Continue diuresis and oxygen therapy as needed.
* Monitor the patient's creatinine levels and adjust medications as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cognitive status and adjust medications as necessary.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust oxygen therapy as necessary.
* Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust medications as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG, diastolic heart failure, and severe PVD. He was admitted for femoral bypass and post-op posterior STEMI and acute on CHF.

The patient has been experiencing worsening standard chest pain (STD) with electrocardiogram (ECG) changes, and has been treated with heparin and nitroglycerin. His cardiac markers are trending down, but he is still experiencing recurrent chest pain.

The patient has been diagnosed with acute on chronic diastolic/acute systolic CHF, and is receiving diuresis and oxygen therapy. He is also suspected to have ICU delirium, and is being treated with haloperidol.

The patient has a history of hypertension, and his blood pressure is borderline. He is being treated with antihypertensive medications, but the plan is to be cautious with medication changes due to his borderline blood pressure.

The patient also has a history of hypercholesterolemia, and is being treated with statin therapy. He is also being considered for cholestyramine as an alternative to statin therapy.

The patient has chronic kidney disease (CKD), and his creatinine level is being monitored. He also has a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and is using a home CPAP machine.

The patient has a history of femoral bypass surgery, and is being followed up with vascular care. He also has a history of gastrointestinal (GI) issues, and is being treated with a low sodium diet and bowel regimen.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of cardiac function: The patient's cardiac markers are trending down, but he is still experiencing recurrent chest pain, which could indicate worsening of his cardiac function.
2. Delirium: The patient is suspected to have ICU delirium, which can be a serious complication in critically ill patients.
3. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is borderline, and he is being treated with antihypertensive medications. If his blood pressure becomes too high, it can lead to complications such as hypertensive crisis.
4. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypercholesterolemia, which can increase his risk of cardiovascular events.
5. CKD: The patient has a history of CKD, and his creatinine level is being monitored. If his creatinine level increases, it can indicate worsening of his kidney function.
6. OSA: The patient has a history of OSA, and is using a home CPAP machine. If he is not using the machine correctly, it can lead to complications such as respiratory failure.
7. GI issues: The patient has a history of GI issues, and is being treated with a low sodium diet and bowel regimen. If his GI issues worsen, it can lead to complications such as sepsis or malnutrition.
8. Infection: The patient has a history of femoral bypass surgery, and is at risk of developing an infection at the surgical site.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a variety of medical complications, and will require close monitoring and management to prevent these complications from occurring.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), femoral-popliteal bypass, and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and acute on chronic heart failure. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management.

The patient's condition has improved over the past 24 hours, with no recurrent episodes of chest pain, and he remains afebrile with no white count. His blood pressure is controlled, and he is able to tolerate oral medications. He has been uptitrated on imdur and metoprolol, and his heparin gtt has been discontinued.

However, the patient's hematocrit (Hct) is trending down, and he has been typed and cross-matched. His platelet count is slightly elevated, and his creatinine (Cr) level is stable. His troponin-T level is elevated, and his CK/CKMB levels are also slightly elevated.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac condition is still unstable, and he may be at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.
2. Bleeding complications: The patient's platelet count is slightly elevated, and he has been on anticoagulation therapy, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
3. Renal complications: The patient's Cr level is stable, but he has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD), and his kidney function may deteriorate further.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient is on oxygen therapy, and he may be at risk for respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.
5. Infection complications: The patient has a history of femoral-popliteal bypass and PCI, which may increase the risk of infection complications, such as wound infection or sepsis.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and he may be at risk for further gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition will continue to be monitored closely in the ICU, and his cardiac, renal, respiratory, and gastrointestinal functions will be closely monitored for any signs of deterioration. His medications will be adjusted as needed to optimize his cardiac and renal function. His platelet count will be monitored regularly to ensure that it remains within a safe range. His Cr level will be monitored regularly to ensure that it does not deteriorate further. His oxygen therapy will be continued, and his respiratory function will be monitored closely for any signs of respiratory failure. His gastrointestinal function will be monitored closely for any signs of bleeding or perforation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), diastolic heart failure, and severe peripheral vascular disease (PVD) who was admitted for femoral bypass surgery and post-operative posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) following percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Vital signs: stable, with a temperature of 98.8°F, heart rate of 64 bpm, blood pressure of 106/66 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: the patient's central venous pressure (CVP) and pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) are stable, with a cardiac output of 4.7 liters per minute.
* Fluid balance: the patient has received a total of 528 mL of intravenous fluids over the past 24 hours, with a total output of 2,330 mL.
* Laboratory results: the patient's white blood cell count (WBC) is 14.7, hemoglobin (Hb) is 10.8 g/dL, and platelet count (PLT) is 54,000.
* Electrolytes: the patient's sodium (Na) level is 136 mEq/L, potassium (K) level is 4.2 mEq/L, and chloride (Cl) level is 99 mEq/L.
* Troponin-T: the patient's troponin-T level is 8.83 ng/mL, indicating ongoing myocardial injury.
* Other lab results: the patient's creatinine (Cr) level is 1.5 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 30 mg/dL, and creatine kinase (CK) level is 130 IU/L.

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continued anticoagulation therapy with warfarin and aspirin
* Uptitration of beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors for further afterload reduction
* Increase in simvastatin to 80 mg daily, with monitoring for adverse effects
* Consideration of cholestyramine as an alternative to statin therapy
* Diuresis goal of -500 to -1000 mL per day
* Weaning of oxygen therapy as tolerated
* Use of albuterol nebulizers as needed for bronchospasm
* Cautious use of antihypertensives due to borderline blood pressure
* Conversion of captopril to lisinopril
* Telemetry monitoring for cardiac rhythm
* Follow-up with vascular surgeon for femoral bypass graft
* Statin therapy for hypercholesterolemia, pending further discussion with the patient
* Monitoring of creatinine and urine output for chronic kidney disease (CKD)
* Use of home continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)
* Low-sodium diet and bowel regimen for gastrointestinal (GI) issues
* Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy for peptic ulcer disease (PUD)
* Peripheral intravenous (PIV) line and removal of right internal jugular (RIJ) catheter

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued myocardial injury and worsening of cardiac function
* Development of acute kidney injury (AKI) or worsening of CKD
* Hypertension or hypotension due to changes in antihypertensive therapy
* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to GI issues
* Infection or sepsis due to PIV line or other invasive devices
* Thrombocytopenia or bleeding due to platelet count decrease
* Hyperkalemia or hypokalemia due to changes in electrolyte levels.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8°F, heart rate of 64 bpm, blood pressure of 106/66 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.7, hemoglobin of 11.3 g/dL, and platelet count of 54. The patient's troponin-T level is elevated at 8.83, indicating cardiac injury. The patient's creatinine level is 1.7 mg/dL, and glucose level is 134 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination is notable for absent radial and digital pulses in both arms, and the patient's skin was not assessed. The patient's neurologic examination was not performed due to the patient's delirium and confusion.

The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, and is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer. The patient is receiving prophylactic anticoagulation with ranitidine and furosemide.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias due to the patient's cardiac injury and medication changes.
2. Infection, particularly pneumonia, due to the patient's delirium and confusion, and the presence of central lines.
3. DVT and pulmonary embolism due to the patient's peripheral vascular disease and immobility.
4. Stress ulcer bleeding due to the patient's cardiac injury and medication changes.
5. Hypoglycemia due to the patient's diabetes and medication changes.
6. Respiratory failure due to the patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and cardiac injury.
7. Septic shock due to the patient's cardiac injury and potential infection.

The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's disposition is unclear.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.8°F, heart rate of 64 bpm, blood pressure of 106/66 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.7, hemoglobin of 11.3 g/dL, and platelet count of 54,000. The patient's creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL, and troponin-T is 8.83 ng/mL.

The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, ischemic heart disease, and peripheral vascular disease without critical limb ischemia. The patient is at risk for delirium and confusion, and the ICU care plan includes prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and ischemic heart disease puts them at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, which can be life-threatening.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, which may indicate respiratory failure. This can lead to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is 1.5 mg/dL, which may indicate kidney dysfunction. Renal failure can lead to electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of ischemic heart disease and peripheral vascular disease may increase their risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and ischemic heart disease may increase their risk for infection, particularly in the setting of a prolonged ICU stay.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their care plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and ensure their optimal recovery.

Summary:

The patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute occlusion of the SVG-OM1 with placement of two BMS, and ongoing chest pain associated with recurrent graft occlusion despite cardiac markers trending down. He has a history of CAD, diastolic heart failure, and severe PVD. The patient's current condition is:

* Chest pain-free after weaning off nitroglycerin and discontinuing heparin
* Oriented and able to sit in a chair with assistance
* Trending down Hct (41.9 to 32.6) and requiring blood transfusions
* On multiple medications including beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, and statins
* Has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and CKD
* Currently has a low sodium diet and bowel regimen

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Recurrent graft occlusion: The patient's ongoing chest pain and cardiac markers trending down may indicate recurrent graft occlusion, which could lead to further complications such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
2. Diastolic heart failure: The patient's history of diastolic heart failure and ongoing chest pain may indicate worsening of this condition, which could lead to further complications such as pulmonary edema or cardiogenic shock.
3. Severe PVD: The patient's severe PVD may lead to further complications such as limb ischemia or gangrene, particularly if the graft occlusion is not resolved.
4. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's poorly controlled hypercholesterolemia may increase his risk of further cardiovascular events, such as myocardial infarction or stroke.
5. CKD: The patient's CKD may worsen if his creatinine levels continue to rise, which could lead to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances or uremic syndrome.
6. Delirium: The patient's suspected ICU delirium may worsen if not addressed, which could lead to further complications such as falls, pressure ulcers, or respiratory failure.
7. Hypertension: The patient's borderline hypertension may worsen if not managed properly, which could lead to further complications such as cardiovascular events, kidney disease, or stroke.

Summary:

The patient, a 70-year-old woman, is a post-operative case of CABG, fem-fem bypass, and posterior STEMI with acute on chronic diastolic and systolic heart failure. She was admitted for post-operative complications and has been in the ICU for several days. The patient has been weaned off nitroglycerin and heparin, and her chest pain has remained under control. Her vital signs are stable, and she is oriented with no significant pain or discomfort.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Graft Occlusion: The patient has a history of recurrent graft occlusion, which may lead to further complications, including recurrent STEMI and heart failure.
2. Mitral Valve Involvement: The patient's mitral valve may be involved, which could lead to further cardiac complications, including mitral regurgitation and heart failure.
3. Delirium: The patient is suspected to have ICU delirium, which could be caused by various factors, including medication, infection, or underlying medical conditions.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is borderline high, which may require careful management to prevent further complications.
5. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient has poorly controlled hypercholesterolemia, which may increase her risk of further cardiac complications.
6. Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient has chronic kidney disease, which may require careful monitoring of her creatinine and urine output.
7. Obstructive Sleep Apnea: The patient has a history of obstructive sleep apnea, which may require further management, including CPAP therapy.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, including constipation, diarrhea, and nausea, due to her medical history and medications.
9. Venous Thromboembolism: The patient is at risk for venous thromboembolism due to her immobility and underlying medical conditions.
10. Infection: The patient may be at risk for infection, particularly pneumonia, due to her underlying medical conditions and immobility.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status, including her graft patency and cardiac function.
2. Manage the patient's delirium with appropriate medications and interventions.
3. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust her antihypertensive regimen as necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypercholesterolemia with statin therapy and consider alternative therapies if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust her medications accordingly.
6. Continue to manage the patient's obstructive sleep apnea with CPAP therapy.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal function and adjust her medications and diet as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient for signs of venous thromboembolism and take appropriate measures to prevent it.
9. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and take appropriate measures to prevent it.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and femoral-popliteal bypass surgery. He developed a posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) following the procedure, which was treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and placement of two bare metal stents.

The patient's current condition is stable, with no recurrent episodes of chest pain. He has been weaned off nitroglycerin and heparin infusions, and his diet has been restarted. His hemodynamic parameters, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation, are within normal limits.

However, the patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's beta blocker therapy has been uptitrated, which may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, particularly sinus pauses.
2. Heart failure: The patient's history of diastolic heart failure and acute systolic heart failure, as well as his current condition of acute on chronic diastolic and acute systolic heart failure, puts him at risk for further heart failure exacerbation.
3. Renal impairment: The patient's creatinine levels are slightly elevated, and he has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD). Further monitoring of his renal function is necessary.
4. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient has poorly controlled hypercholesterolemia, which may increase his risk of cardiovascular events.
5. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): The patient has a history of COPD, which may worsen his respiratory status.
6. Chronic kidney disease (CKD): The patient's creatinine levels are slightly elevated, and he has a history of CKD. Further monitoring of his renal function is necessary.
7. Osteoporosis: The patient's history of osteoporosis may increase his risk of fractures, particularly with his current condition of heart failure and chronic kidney disease.

Based on these findings, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust his beta blocker therapy as necessary to prevent cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's heart failure status and adjust his diuretic therapy as necessary to prevent exacerbation of heart failure.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly to prevent further exacerbation of CKD.
4. Consider adding cholestyramine to the patient's statin therapy to improve his hypercholesterolemia.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as necessary to prevent further exacerbation of COPD.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's osteoporosis and consider starting bisphosphonate therapy to prevent further bone loss.

In conclusion, the patient's current condition is stable, but he is at risk for several potential medical complications. Close monitoring and adjustments to his therapy as necessary are crucial to prevent further exacerbation of his conditions.

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and was admitted for femoral-femoral bypass with a post-operative posterior ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) and acute-on-chronic heart failure (HF).

The patient's current condition is stable, with no recurrent episodes of chest pain since weaning off nitroglycerin and heparin. The patient's hemodynamic parameters are within normal limits, with a blood pressure of 106/66 mmHg and a heart rate of 64 beats per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.7 K/uL, a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL, and a platelet count of 54 K/uL. The patient's creatinine level is 1.5 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 30 mEq/L.

The patient's medical conditions include acute-on-chronic diastolic and systolic HF, hypercholesterolemia, chronic kidney disease (CKD), and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The patient is also at risk for delirium, hypertension, and peripheral vascular disease (PVD).

The patient's plan of care includes continued treatment with aspirin, clopidogrel, and simvastatin, as well as diuresis to achieve a goal of 500 mL of urine output per day. The patient will also continue to receive oxygen therapy and bronchodilators as needed.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of HF: The patient's HF is currently stable, but it may worsen if the patient's condition deteriorates.
2. Delirium: The patient is at risk for delirium, which can be caused by a variety of factors, including medication side effects, sleep deprivation, and underlying medical conditions.
3. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is borderline high, and it may worsen if the patient's condition deteriorates.
4. PVD: The patient has a history of PVD, which may worsen if the patient's condition deteriorates.
5. CKD: The patient has CKD, which may worsen if the patient's condition deteriorates.
6. OSA: The patient has a history of OSA, which may worsen if the patient's condition deteriorates.
7. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient has poorly controlled hypercholesterolemia, which may worsen if the patient's condition deteriorates.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, but it is important to continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care as needed to prevent potential medical complications.
